column69: Custom field ([CHART] Date of First Response)

column26:
* Compared the performance of all models side by side to determine which model performed the best.
* Visualized model performance using appropriate plots (e.g., *ROC curves*, *Precision-Recall curves*, *Feature Importance* plots).
* Analyzed the *trade-offs* between precision and recall to ensure that the selected model minimizes both false positives and false negatives.

* *Choose Best Model*:
** After comparing the performance of all models, selected the model that performed the best based on the evaluation metrics.
** Justified the choice of the best model based on its overall performance and suitability for the fraud detection task (e.g., higher recall for fraud detection)

*Objective*:
The goal of this task was to write code that evaluates all trained models (Decision Tree, AdaBoost, Logistic Regression, and XGBoost) and selects the best model based on performance metrics.

* Trained an *XGBoost* classifier, utilizing the boosted trees technique for improved performance.
* Tuned hyperparameters like {{learning_rate}}, {{max_depth}}, {{n_estimators}}, and {{subsample}} using *GridSearchCV* or *RandomizedSearchCV*.
* Evaluated the model using performance metrics like *accuracy*, *precision*, *recall*, and *F1 score*.

* Trained an *AdaBoost* classifier with a base estimator (e.g., Decision Tree) to enhance weak models.
* Optimized the number of estimators ({{n_estimators}}) and learning rate.
* Evaluated performance using classification metrics (e.g., *accuracy*, *ROC AUC*)

* Performed *feature scaling* on numerical columns to standardize or normalize the data (e.g., using *StandardScaler* or *MinMaxScaler*).
* Scaling ensures that all numerical features have the same scale, which helps improve the performance of many machine learning algorithms, especially distance-based algorithms like k-NN or SVM

column1: Descriptive Statistics for Numerical Columns and Categoric columns
column26:
Generated descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, median, standard deviation, min, max, quartiles) for numerical columns to get a sense of the data’s central tendency and spread.

Visualized the distribution of numerical columns (e.g., using histograms, box plots) to identify skewness, outliers, and patterns in the data

For categorical columns, calculated the count and frequency of each category to understand the distribution and identify any imbalances in the data (e.g., using value counts or bar charts).

Separated and identified categorical and numerical columns in the dataset for appropriate analysis and visualization.

* *Categorical columns*: e.g., gender, category, payment method.
* *Numerical columns*: e.g., quantity, price, total spending, age.
Checked the shape of the dataframe to understand the number of rows and columns. This helped in assessing the size and complexity of the dataset

* Trained a *Decision Tree* classifier on the training dataset.
* Tuned hyperparameters like {{max_depth}}, {{min_samples_split}}, and {{min_samples_leaf}} using *GridSearchCV* (if applicable) to optimize model performance.
* Evaluated the model using metrics like *accuracy*, *precision*, *recall*, and *F1 score*.

* Trained a *Logistic Regression* model using the training data.
* Evaluated the model using *accuracy* and other metrics (e.g., *precision*, *recall*).

The goal of this task was to build multiple machine learning models (Decision Tree, AdaBoost, Logistic Regression, and XGBoost) on the preprocessed data and evaluate their performance to identify the best model for fraud detection.
* Applied encoding techniques (e.g., *One-Hot Encoding* or *Label Encoding*) to transform categorical variables into numerical format, which is necessary for machine learning models.

* Identified outliers in numerical features (e.g., using box plots, Z-score, or IQR).
* Decided how to handle outliers: either by removing them, capping them, or transforming the data to reduce their impact on the model.

* Handled missing values in both the training and test sets using an appropriate strategy (e.g., mean/median imputation for numerical features, mode imputation for categorical features).
* This ensures that the model can be trained without issues caused by missing data.

column1: Split Data into Train and Test
column26:
* Split the dataset into *training* and *test* sets to ensure that the model is trained on a portion of the data and evaluated on unseen data.
* This step is crucial for evaluating the performance of the model and avoiding overfitting

*Objective*:
The goal of this task was to perform feature engineering on the fraud detection dataset, which involved preparing the data for model training by handling missing values, detecting and handling outliers, encoding categorical variables, and scaling numerical features.
Verified the data types of each column in the dataset to ensure that they were appropriate for analysis (e.g., integers, floats, strings, dates).

*Objective*:
The goal of this task was to perform exploratory data analysis (EDA) on the fraud detection dataset to better understand the data and prepare it for the next stages of the project.

*Steps Taken*:

# *Checked Data Types*:
#* Verified the data types of each column in the dataset to ensure that they were appropriate for analysis (e.g., integers, floats, strings, dates).
# *Data Shape*:
#* Checked the shape of the dataframe to understand the number of rows and columns. This helped in assessing the size and complexity of the dataset.
# *Count of Missing Values*:
#* Identified and counted missing values in each column to understand the extent of any data quality issues and decide how to handle them (e.g., imputation, removal).
# *Categorical and Numerical Columns*:
#* Separated and identified categorical and numerical columns in the dataset for appropriate analysis and visualization.
#** *Categorical columns*: e.g., gender, category, payment method.
#** *Numerical columns*: e.g., quantity, price, total spending, age.
# *Descriptive Statistics for Numerical Columns*:
#* Generated descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, median, standard deviation, min, max, quartiles) for numerical columns to get a sense of the data’s central tendency and spread.
# *Distribution of Numerical Columns*:
#* Visualized the distribution of numerical columns (e.g., using histograms, box plots) to identify skewness, outliers, and patterns in the data.
# *Descriptive Statistics for Categorical Columns*:
#* For categorical columns, calculated the count and frequency of each category to understand the distribution and identify any imbalances in the data (e.g., using value counts or bar charts).
